rule.name: BuckStyleImmutableMustBePackagePrivate
rule.description:
Value types decorated with @BuckStyleImmutable must be package-private (i.e., not public or private).
The build will automatically generate a public subclass or implementation of your value type. All clients should use that API, so the parent value type should limit its visibility as much as possible.

rule.name: BuckStyleImmutableNameMustStartWithAbstract
rule.message: Name of @BuckStyleImmutable value types must start with Abstract
rule.description:
Value types decorated with @BuckStyleImmutable must have a name starting with 'Abstract'
The build will automatically generate a subclass or implementation of your value type without 'Abstract' in the name.

rule.name: BlacklistedDefaultCharsetMethods
rule.message: These APIs implicitly use the system default Charset. Use explicit ones instead.
rule.description: We blacklist (disallow) use of APIs which implicitly use the system default Charset. Instead, use APIs which explicitly take a Charset argument.

rule.name: BlacklistedDefaultProcessMethod
rule.message: All subprocess creation should go through BgProcessKiller.
rule.description: We use a process-group-wide signal to kill all our subprocesses on demand; we need to synchronize this kill operation with process creation to ensure that no process gets created with SIG_IGN for SIGHUP.

rule.name: BlacklistedJavaUtilLoggerUsage
rule.description: Buck uses a custom Logger which does custom formatting and maybe other things. java.util.logging.Logger bypasses this.

rule.name: BlacklistedPrintWriterUsage
rule.description: java.io.PrintWriter eats IOExceptions. Using it when writing build artifacts and metadata risks generation of corrupted artifacts when I/O operations fail (such as in low-disk-space situations).

rule.name: SimplifyStringReplace
rule.message: [perf] Use String.replace(char, char) for one-character replacements
rule.description:
Use String.replace('\\', '/') instead of String.replace("\\", "/")
String#replace(char, char) is extremely efficient. String#replace(String, String) has to compile and execute a regular expression. Always prefer the former when doing single-character replacements.

rule.name: BlacklistedSystemGetenv
rule.description: System.getenv() returns environment variables with names that may be case-insensitive on some OSes (for example, Windows). EnvVariablesProvider.getSystemEnv() returns unified variables with names converted to upper cases.
